awd_titl_txt: RCN: Research Network in Hybrid Simulation for Multi-Hazard Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Hybrid simulation is a powerful cyber-physical research methodology that integrates physical experimentation with computational simulation to observe and evaluate the performance of engineering systems under realistic conditions. Originally pioneered in the field of earthquake engineering, hybrid simulation includes a suite of efficient and cost-effective techniques that has potential for broad application across many science and engineering disciplines. For example, such experimental evaluation of new design concepts and devices is intended to examine the performance of civil infrastructure, such as buildings and lifelines, when exposed to natural hazards, such as earthquakes and windstorms.  Thus, these experiments enable knowledge generation and innovations that will reduce fatalities, maintain business continuity, and minimize economic losses resulting from natural hazards. A growing interdisciplinary and international community of researchers is using hybrid simulation to address societal grand challenge problems related to multi-hazard engineering. However, existing technical barriers have limited advancements in hybrid simulation. This research coordination network will be established to accelerate progress in advanced hybrid simulation methodologies to address societal grand challenges, build capacity in a range of laboratories, and build partnerships among engineering disciplines.  

This research coordination network aims to facilitate the scientific advances needed to establish the theory of and expand the capacity for hybrid simulation as it applies to multi-hazard engineering. The specific objectives are to: (1) diversify, broaden, and expand the community of researchers in hybrid simulation, (2) foster peer-to-peer and institute-to-institute partnerships that will be able to tackle the scientific challenges that lie ahead, (3) develop the common research agenda for hybrid simulation, (4) share digital artifacts, such as open-source data, models, lectures, techniques, and tools, across laboratories and disciplinary boundaries, (5) build the capacity for hybrid simulation in a greater number of existing laboratories, and (6) cultivate international collaborations to share knowledge and enable access to resources. These objectives will be achieved through activities such as focused workshops, online networking, sharing of resources, peer-to-peer communications, international partnerships, research agenda development, and dissemination activities. Digital artifacts, such as computational models, experimental data, and learning materials, will be gathered and shared through the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure Designsafe-ci.org web portal. A diverse, core group of junior faculty and graduate students will be engaged, while senior and mid-career faculty also will participate and share expertise. By breaking down the existing technical barriers that have limited the advancement of hybrid simulation methods, this broader community of researchers will be prepared to solve societal grand challenge problems related to natural hazard events.

por.por_cntn:
Hybrid simulation is a powerful class of cyber-physical techniques that integrates physical experimentation with computational simulation to observe and evaluate the performance of engineering systems under realistic conditions that are either too large or too complex to fit in a single laboratory. MECHS was established in 2017 as a Research Coordination Network to (i) diversify, broaden and expand the community of researchers in hybrid simulation; (ii) foster peer-to-peer and institute-to-institute partnerships that will be able to tackle the scientific challenges that lie ahead; (iii) develop a common research agenda for hybrid simulation; (iv) share digital artifacts such as open-source data, models, lectures, techniques and tools; (v) build capacity for hybrid simulation in a greater number of existing laboratories; and, (vi) cultivate international collaborations to share knowledge and enable access to resources.

The following activities have been accomplished during the project period: 

MECHS developed and evolved a Research Agenda that summarizes the technical knowledge needed to enable transformative changes in the ability to conduct high-impact hybrid simulations and real-time hybrid simulation (RTHS) classified into the four categories: algorithms, enabling technologies, fundamental theory, and community building and learning.

Workshops focused on broad research needs as well as key topics such as machine learning, wind engineering, fluid-structure interaction problems, and computational bottlenecks were organized. MECHS community members were provided with the opportunity to join in these discussions and network with potential collaborators interested in similar or complementary problems. Tackling multi-hazard problems was a particular focus of these workshops. 

MECHS organized a number of webinars for the community, to enable students and researchers alike to learn about cutting edge research taking place around the world.  

Community problem statements provide access to rigorously-developed problem statements and reveal the technical challenges and research opportunities. Thus they are important for training new graduate students, for learning how to deal with uncertainty and experimental error, and for comparing and contrasting methods to evaluate performance. 

  • Problem for Single-axis RTHS considering a seismically excited building has been developed, and is presented to the community with the aim to advance the field. Realistic models of the physical components, parametric uncertainties, and control constraints are used. We anticipate that the lessons learned through this benchmark problem will provide a clear basis for evaluating the efficacy of various transfer system control strategies and expose research questions
  • Problem for Nonlinear RTHS includes a complete virtual RTHS code package to interested attendees of the 2022 NHERI Summit. The MECHS community was invited to try this problem statement to learn more about RTHS and control design. 
  • Problem for Multi-axial RTHS presents a multi-axial control problem focused on a frame subjected to seismic load at the base. This maRTHS benchmark includes experimental data for system identification, identified models with uncertainty, finite element models, control constraints, and a code package. This problem considerably transforms the research needs and escalates its complexity, and will facilitate a more realistic examination of the dynamic behavior of structural systems. 

Additional opportunities to engage the community included: 

  • Collaborated with NHERI to participate in the NHERI Summer Institute and the 2022 NHERI Summit 
  • Developed a RTHS Curriculum, based around a series of YouTube videos from leading professors and institutions around the USA. A flow chart guides students through the curriculum, and put all of that information on the website.
  • Organized several special issues in prominent journals 
  • Organized competitions including a 3-minute dissertation video competition

Impact:

By surveying the hybrid simulation community and the participants in our workshops we heard: 

“I see the future of Hybrid Simulation as a tool, not only a purely research topic itself. Just like Performance Based Earthquake Engineering was purely research in the 2000's and now is something you can ask in a normal project.”

"The hands-on activities, the state-of-the-art presentation, and the informative discussions, all have helped engaging more people in RTHS, and helped letting people know more about RTHS."

Participant's comments also emphasize the need for future workshops and activities, as the future of hybrid simulation testing methods is quite promising for mitigating the effects of multiple hazards. 

Representative publications that grew out of this project include: 

Silva, Gomez, Maghareh, Dyke, and Spencer (2020). "Benchmark Control Problem for Real-Time Hybrid Simulation," Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing, 135 (1), 2020, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ymssp.2019.106381. 

Najafi, Fermandois, Dyke, and Spencer. (2023). "Hybrid simulation with multiple actuators: a state-of-the-art review," Engineering Structures, 276, p. 115284, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.engstruct.2022.115284
